	doi = {10.1177/0265813516647061},
	issn = {2399-8083},
	number = {3},
	date = {2016-05-12},
	language = {en},
	pages = {504--530},
	publisher = {SAGE Publications},
	title = {Using space syntax and {Q}-analysis for investigating movement patterns in buildings: The case of shopping malls},
	url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0265813516647061},
	volume = {44},
}

text.content: <jats:p>In this study, we present the potential of the conjunction between space syntax and Q-analysis methodologies for investigating patterns of movement flows in buildings. This potential is illustrated by an implementation of the two methodologies by comparing between two shopping malls in Israel, which are characterized by distinct spatial configurations. Q-analysis was used to identify the spread of individuals‚Äô movement paths and their conjunction into movement areas, while space syntax enabled to examine how these aspects of movement flow are affected by the malls‚Äô spatial configuration. The results indicate that high spatial integration and intelligibility levels not only promote intensive movement in accessible and central areas (as found in previous studies) but also the spread of movement paths and their formation to integrated circulation systems. The combined implementation of space syntax and Q-analysis improves our understanding about the role of building‚Äô spatial configuration in shaping movement flows. We discuss the potential of this implementation for monitoring and improving movement flow and usability of spaces in buildings.</jats:p>

text.content:
@article{Gu2019Indoor,
	abstract = {\textless{}jats:p\textgreater{}Indoor localization is essential for healthcare, security, augmented reality gaming, and many other location-based services. There is currently a wealth of relevant literature on indoor localization. This article focuses on recent advances in indoor localization methods that use spatial context to improve the location estimation. Spatial context in the form of maps and spatial models have been used to improve the localization by constraining location estimates in the navigable parts of indoor environments. Landmarks such as doors and corners, which are also one form of spatial context, have proved useful in assisting indoor localization by correcting the localization error. This survey gives a comprehensive review of state-of-the-art indoor localization methods and localization improvement methods using maps, spatial models, and landmarks.\textless{}/jats:p\textgreater{}},
	author = {Gu, Fuqiang and Hu, Xuke and Ramezani, Milad and Acharya, Debaditya and Khoshelham, Kourosh and Valaee, Shahrokh and Shang, Jianga},
	journaltitle = {ACM Computing Surveys},
	shortjournal = {ACM Comput. Surv.},

text.content:
@article{Yoshimura2014Analysis,
	abstract = {\textless{}jats:p\textgreater{} Museums often suffer from so-called \textquoteleft{}hypercongestion\textquoteright{}, wherein the number of visitors exceeds the capacity of the physical space of the museum. This can potentially be detrimental to the quality of visitors' experiences, through disturbance by the behavior and presence of other visitors. Although this situation can be mitigated by managing visitors' flow between spaces, a detailed analysis of visitor movement is required to realize fully and apply a proper solution to the problem. In this paper we analyze visitors' sequential movements, the spatial layout, and the relationship between them in a large- scale art museum---The Louvre Museum---using anonymized data collected through noninvasive Bluetooth sensors. This enables us to unveil some features of visitor behavior and spatial impact that shed some light on the mechanisms of museum overcrowding. The analysis reveals that the visiting styles of short-stay and long-stay visitors are not as significantly different as one might expect. Both types of visitors tend to visit a similar number of key locations in the museum while the longer-stay visitors just tend to do so more time extensively. In addition, we reveal that some ways of exploring the museum appear frequently for both types of visit},
	author = {Yoshimura, Yuji and Sobolevsky, Stanislav and Ratti, Carlo and Girardin, Fabien and Carrascal, Juan Pablo and Blat, Josep and Sinatra, Roberta},
	journaltitle = {Environment and Planning B: Planning and Design},
	shortjournal = {Environ Plann B Plann Des},
	doi = {10.1068/b130047p},
	issn = {0265-8135},
	number = {6},
	date = {2014-12},
	language = {en},
	pages = {1113--1131},
	publisher = {SAGE Publications},
	title = {An {Analysis} of {Visitors}' {Behavior} in the {Louvre} {Museum}: A {Study} {Using} {Bluetooth} {Data}},
	url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1068/b130047p},
	volume = {41},
}

text.content: <jats:p> Museums often suffer from so-called ‚Äòhypercongestion‚Äô, wherein the number of visitors exceeds the capacity of the physical space of the museum. This can potentially be detrimental to the quality of visitors' experiences, through disturbance by the behavior and presence of other visitors. Although this situation can be mitigated by managing visitors' flow between spaces, a detailed analysis of visitor movement is required to realize fully and apply a proper solution to the problem. In this paper we analyze visitors' sequential movements, the spatial layout, and the relationship between them in a large- scale art museum‚ÄîThe Louvre Museum‚Äîusing anonymized data collected through noninvasive Bluetooth sensors. This enables us to unveil some features of visitor behavior and spatial impact that shed some light on the mechanisms of museum overcrowding. The analysis reveals that the visiting styles of short-stay and long-stay visitors are not as significantly different as one might expect. Both types of visitors tend to visit a similar number of key locations in the museum while the longer-stay visitors just tend to do so more time extensively. In addition, we reveal that some ways of exploring the museum appear frequently for both types of visitors, although long-stay visitors might be expected to diversify much more, given the greater time spent in the museum. We suggest that these similarities and dissimilarities make for an uneven distribution of the number of visitors in the museum space. The findings increase the understanding of the unknown behaviors of visitors, which is key to improving the museum's environment and visitor experience. </jats:p>

In this paper we analyze visitors' sequential movements, the spatial layout, and the relationship between them in a large- scale art museum‚ÄîThe Louvre Museum‚Äîusing anonymized data collected through noninvasive Bluetooth sensors. Abstract: <jats:p> Museums often suffer from so-called ‚Äòhypercongestion‚Äô, wherein the number of visitors exceeds the capacity of the physical space of the museum. This can potentially be detrimental to the quality of visitors' experiences, through disturbance by the behavior and presence of other visitors. Although this situation can be mitigated by managing visitors' flow between spaces, a detailed analysis of visitor movement is required to realize fully and apply a proper solution to the problem. In this paper we analyze visitors' sequential movements, the spatial layout, and the relationship between them in a large- scale art museum‚ÄîThe Louvre Museum‚Äîusing anonymized data collected through noninvasive Bluetooth sensors. This enables us to unveil some features of visitor behavior and spatial impact that shed some light on the mechanisms of museum overcrowding. The analysis reveals that the visiting styles of short-stay and long-stay visitors are not as significantly different as one might expect. Both types of visitors tend to visit a similar number of key locations in the museum while the longer-stay visitors just tend to do so more time extensively. In addition, we reveal that some ways of exploring the museum appear frequently for both types of visitors, although long-stay visitors might be expected to diversify much more, given the greater time spent in the museum. We suggest that these similarities and dissimilarities make for an uneven distribution of the number of visitors in the museum space. The findings increase the understanding of the unknown behaviors of visitors, which is key to improving the museum's environment and visitor experience. </jats:p>

text.content:
@article{Want1992active,
	abstract = {\textless{}jats:p\textgreater{}A novel system for the location of people in an office environment is described. Members of staff wear badges that transmit signals providing information about their location to a centralized location service, through a network of sensors. The paper also examines alternative location techniques, system design issues and applications, particularly relating to telephone call routing. Location systems raise concerns about the privacy of an individual and these issues are also addressed.\textless{}/jats:p\textgreater{}},
	author = {Want, Roy and Hopper, Andy and Falc{\~ a}o, Veronica and Gibbons, Jonathan},
	journaltitle = {ACM Transactions on Information Systems},
	shortjournal = {ACM Trans. Inf. Syst.},
	doi = {10.1145/128756.128759},
	issn = {1046-8188},
	number = {1},
	date = {1992-01-02},
	language = {en},
	pages = {91--102},
	publisher = {Association for Computing Machinery (ACM)},
	title = {The active badge location system},
	url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1145/128756.128759},
	volume = {10},
}

Location systems raise concerns about the privacy of an individual and these issues are also addressed.</jats:p>

text.content:
@article{Lau2006Understanding,
	abstract = {\textless{}jats:p\textgreater{} This paper presents preliminary findings of research examining the movement patterns of tourists within a destination. The study focuses on fully independent individual travellers visiting Hong Kong. Little research has been conducted looking at movements within a destination. Macro or inter-destination movement patterns may inform intra-destination movements. Factors affecting tourists' choices of itineraries give reasons to support the shaping of the patterns. These factors include human factors (type of individual, travel party, motivations, etc), physical factors (destination geomorphology), trip factors (main or secondary destination, first-time or repeat visitor, etc) and the time factor (length of stay in destination, total trip duration). Geographic Information System is used for documenting spatial---temporal movements of tourists through mapping. \textless{}/jats:p\textgreater{}},
	author = {Lau, Gigi and McKercher, Bob},
	journaltitle = {Tourism and Hospitality Research},
	shortjournal = {Tourism and Hospitality Research},
	doi = {10.1057/palgrave.thr.6050027},
	issn = {1467-3584},
	number = {1},
	date = {2006-11},
	language = {en},
	pages = {39--49},
	publisher = {SAGE Publications},
	title = {Understanding {Tourist} {Movement} {Patterns} in a {Destination}: A {GIS} {Approach}},
	url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1057/palgrave.thr.6050027},
	volume = {7},
}

text.content: <jats:p> This paper presents preliminary findings of research examining the movement patterns of tourists within a destination. The study focuses on fully independent individual travellers visiting Hong Kong. Little research has been conducted looking at movements within a destination. Macro or inter-destination movement patterns may inform intra-destination movements. Factors affecting tourists' choices of itineraries give reasons to support the shaping of the patterns. These factors include human factors (type of individual, travel party, motivations, etc), physical factors (destination geomorphology), trip factors (main or secondary destination, first-time or repeat visitor, etc) and the time factor (length of stay in destination, total trip duration). Geographic Information System is used for documenting spatial‚Äîtemporal movements of tourists through mapping. </jats:p>

text.content:
@article{Vogel2022Supervised,
	abstract = {\textless{}jats:p\textgreater{}The projection into a virtual character and the concomitant illusionary body ownership can lead to transformations of one\textquoteright{}s entity. Both during and after the exposure, behavioural and attitudinal changes may occur, depending on the characteristics or stereotypes associated with the embodied avatar. In the present study, we investigated the effects on physical activity when young students experience being old. After assignment (at random) to a young or an older avatar, the participants\textquoteright{} body movements were tracked while performing upper body exercises. We propose and discuss the use of supervised learning procedures to assign these movement patterns to the underlying avatar class in order to detect behavioural differences. This approach can be seen as an alternative to classical feature-wise testing. We found that the classification accuracy was remarkably good for support vector machines with linear kernel and deep learning by convolutional neural networks, when inserting time sub-sequences extracted at random and repeatedly from the original data. For hand movements, associated decision boundaries revealed a higher level of local, vertical positions for the young avatar group, indicating increased agility in their performances. This occurrence held for both guided movements as well as achievement-orientated exercises.\textless{}/jats:p\textgreater{}},
	author = {Vogel, Frederike and Vahle, Nils M. and Gertheiss, Jan and Tomasik, Martin J.},
	journaltitle = {Royal Society Open Science},
	shortjournal = {R. Soc. open sci.},
	doi = {10.1098/rsos.211594},
	issn = {2054-5703},
	number = {4},
	date = {2022-04},
	language = {en},
	publisher = {The Royal Society},
	title = {Supervised learning for analysing movement patterns in a virtual reality experiment},
	url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rsos.211594},
	volume = {9},
}

text.content: <jats:p>The projection into a virtual character and the concomitant illusionary body ownership can lead to transformations of one‚Äôs entity. Both during and after the exposure, behavioural and attitudinal changes may occur, depending on the characteristics or stereotypes associated with the embodied avatar. In the present study, we investigated the effects on physical activity when young students experience being old. After assignment (at random) to a young or an older avatar, the participants‚Äô body movements were tracked while performing upper body exercises. We propose and discuss the use of supervised learning procedures to assign these movement patterns to the underlying avatar class in order to detect behavioural differences. This approach can be seen as an alternative to classical feature-wise testing. We found that the classification accuracy was remarkably good for support vector machines with linear kernel and deep learning by convolutional neural networks, when inserting time sub-sequences extracted at random and repeatedly from the original data. For hand movements, associated decision boundaries revealed a higher level of local, vertical positions for the young avatar group, indicating increased agility in their performances. This occurrence held for both guided movements as well as achievement-orientated exercises.</jats:p>

This approach can be seen as an alternative to classical feature-wise testing. We found that the classification accuracy was remarkably good for support vector machines with linear kernel and deep learning by convolutional neural networks, when inserting time sub-sequences extracted at random and repeatedly from the original data. For hand movements, associated decision boundaries revealed a higher level of local, vertical positions for the young avatar group, indicating increased agility in their performances. This occurrence held for both guided movements as well as achievement-orientated exercises.</jats:p>

text.content:
@article{Winter2019Infrastructure,
	abstract = {\textless{}jats:p\textgreater{}
            In the absence of any global positioning infrastructure for indoor environments, research on supporting human indoor localization and navigation trails decades behind research on outdoor localization and navigation. The major barrier to broader progress has been the dependency of indoor positioning on environment-specific infrastructure and resulting tailored technical solutions. Combined with the fragmentation and compartmentalization of indoor environments, this poses significant challenges to widespread adoption of indoor location-based services. This article puts aside all approaches of infrastructure-based support for human indoor localization and navigation and instead reviews technical concepts that are
            \textless{}jats:italic\textgreater{}independent\textless{}/jats:italic\textgreater{}
            of sensors embedded in the environment. The reviewed concepts rely on a mobile computing platform with sensing capability and a human interaction interface (``smartphone''). This platform may or may not carry a stored map of the environment, but does not require
            \textless{}jats:italic\textgreater{}in situ\textless{}/jats:italic\textgreater{}
            internet access. In this regard, the presented approaches are more challenging than any localization and navigation solutions specific to a part},
	author = {Winter, Stephan and Tomko, Martin and Vasardani, Maria and Richter, Kai-Florian and Khoshelham, Kourosh and Kalantari, Mohsen},
	journaltitle = {ACM Computing Surveys},
	shortjournal = {ACM Comput. Surv.},
	doi = {10.1145/3321516},
	issn = {0360-0300},
	number = {3},
	date = {2019-06-18},
	language = {en},
	pages = {1--24},
	publisher = {Association for Computing Machinery (ACM)},
	title = {Infrastructure-{Independent} {Indoor} {Localization} and {Navigation}},
	url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.1145/3321516},
	volume = {52},
}

text.content:
<jats:p>
            In the absence of any global positioning infrastructure for indoor environments, research on supporting human indoor localization and navigation trails decades behind research on outdoor localization and navigation. The major barrier to broader progress has been the dependency of indoor positioning on environment-specific infrastructure and resulting tailored technical solutions. Combined with the fragmentation and compartmentalization of indoor environments, this poses significant challenges to widespread adoption of indoor location-based services. This article puts aside all approaches of infrastructure-based support for human indoor localization and navigation and instead reviews technical concepts that are
            <jats:italic>independent</jats:italic>
            of sensors embedded in the environment. The reviewed concepts rely on a mobile computing platform with sensing capability and a human interaction interface (‚Äúsmartphone‚Äù). This platform may or may not carry a stored map of the environment, but does not require
            <jats:italic>in situ</jats:italic>
            internet access. In this regard, the presented approaches are more challenging than any localization and navigation solutions specific to a particular, infrastructure-equipped indoor space, since they are not adapted to local context, and they may lack some of the accuracy achievable with those tailored solutions. However, only these approaches have the potential to be universally applicable.
          </jats:p>

rich_text.plain_text:
<jats:p>
            In the absence of any global positioning infrastructure for indoor environments, research on supporting human indoor localization and navigation trails decades behind research on outdoor localization and navigation. The major barrier to broader progress has been the dependency of indoor positioning on environment-specific infrastructure and resulting tailored technical solutions. Combined with the fragmentation and compartmentalization of indoor environments, this poses significant challenges to widespread adoption of indoor location-based services. This article puts aside all approaches of infrastructure-based support for human indoor localization and navigation and instead reviews technical concepts that are
            <jats:italic>independent</jats:italic>
            of sensors embedded in the environment. The reviewed concepts rely on a mobile computing platform with sensing capability and a human interaction interface (‚Äúsmartphone‚Äù). This platform may or may not carry a stored map of the environment, but does not require
            <jats:italic>in situ</jats:italic>
            internet access. In this regard, the presented approaches are more challenging than any localization and navigation solutions specific to a particular, infrastructure-equipped indoor space, since they are not adapted to local context, and they may lack some of the accuracy achievable with those tailored solutions. However, only these approaches have the potential to be universally applicable.
          </jats:p>
